scenario:
Dividend-paying stocks have provided higher average annual returns over the past 50 years compared to non-dividend payers. From 1973 to 2023, dividend growers and initiators had an average annual total return of 10.19%, while dividend payers had a return of 9.17%. Dividend non-payers and shrinkers had returns of 4.27% and -0.63%, respectively. The equal-weighted S&P 500 index had a return of 7.72%.

Investing in dividend-paying stocks can lead to significant wealth growth over time. For example, investing $6,000 per year at an 8% annual return can result in $38,016 in 5 years, $93,873 in 10 years, and $296,538 in 20 years. Investing twice that amount can result in $76,032 in 5 years, $187,746 in 10 years, and $593,076 in 20 years.

To invest in dividend-paying stocks, one can either select individual stocks or use dividend-focused exchange-traded funds (ETFs). Some popular dividend ETFs include the SPDR Portfolio S&P 500 High Dividend ETF, Schwab U.S. Dividend Equity ETF, and Vanguard High Dividend Yield ETF. These ETFs track an index of dividend performers or have managers identifying good dividend-paying companies, offering instant diversification.

Some individual stocks with high dividend yields include Altria (7.62%), Dow (7.08%), and Verizon Communications (6.65%). However, it's essential to research and evaluate stocks carefully, as high-yield companies can be in trouble. A more straightforward approach is to invest in dividend-focused ETFs, which can provide a diversified portfolio of dividend payers.
